sub_topic: Synthesis of nylon-6,6 from adipic acid and hexamethylenediamine
message_1: What is the maximum yield of nylon-6,6 that can be obtained from the reaction of adipic acid and hexamethylenediamine, assuming complete conversion of the reactants?
message_2:
To determine the maximum yield of nylon-6,6 from the reaction of adipic acid and hexamethylenediamine, we need to consider the stoichiometry of the reaction. The reaction can be represented as follows:

H2N-(CH2)6-NH2 + HOOC-(CH2)4-COOH â†’ [-NH-(CH2)6-NH-CO-(CH2)4-COO-]n + H2O

Here, one molecule of hexamethylenediamine (H2N-(CH2)6-NH2) reacts with one molecule of adipic acid (HOOC-(CH2)4-COOH) to form one unit of nylon-6,6 ([-NH-(CH2)6-NH-CO-(CH2)4-COO-]n) and one molecule of water (H2O).

Assuming complete conversion of the reactants, the maximum yield of nylon-6,6 will be equal to the amount of the limiting reactant. If both reactants are present in equimolar amounts, the maximum yield of nylon-6,6 will be equal to the amount of either reactant.

To calculate the yield in grams, you can use the molar masses of the reactants and the product:

Molar mass of hexamethylenediamine = 116.21 g/mol
Molar mass of adipic acid = 146.14 g/mol
Molar mass of one unit of nylon-6,6 = 226.32 g/mol (excluding water)

If you know the amount of either reactant in moles or grams, you can calculate the maximum yield of nylon-6,6 in grams using the stoichiometry and molar masses.
